sen.j: 違勅（いちょく）とは、天皇の勅に違うことによる罪のこと。
sen.e: Ichoku means a guilt of not following an Emperor's command.

sen.j: 本来の律令法における趣旨は勅の手続に違う者に対して適用される罪であったが、後に勅の内容あるいは勅使に抵抗する行為を指すようになった。
sen.e: Based on the Ritsuryo law, the original purpose of the Ichoku was to apply the guilt of Ichoku to individuals who went against the procedures in an Imperial command, but the Ichoku got to mean an act or behavior of resistance against an Imperial command or an Imperial envoy in a later year.

Based on the Ritsuryo law, the original purpose of the Ichoku was to apply the Punishment of Ichoku to individuals who went against the procedures contained in an Imperial command, but in later years, the Ichoku changed to mean an act or behavior which signified resistance against an Imperial command or an Imperial envoy.

Based on the Ritsuryo law, the original purpose of the Ichoku was to apply the Charge of Ichoku to individuals who went against the procedures contained in an Imperial command, but in later years, the Ichoku changed to mean an act or behavior which signified resistance against an Imperial command or an Imperial envoy.

sen.j: ただし、その罪の適用は格式によって拡大されてきたと考えられ、明法家の間でもその具体的な適用範囲などについては意見の相違があった。
sen.e: The application of the guilt of Ichoku is thought to have been expanded according to ranks, and there was a difference in opinions of Myobo-ke about the actual scope of application.

sen.j: 中世以後においては、「公家御下知違背事也」（『沙汰未練書』）と解され、漠然と天皇の命令に逆らうことと考えられる。
sen.e: In and after the Middle Ages, the Ichoku was recognized as 'Kugegogeji Ihaikotonari (公家御下知違背事也)' ("Satamirensho (沙汰未練書)"), and it is thought to go against an Emperor's command without clear reason.

In and after the Middle Ages, the Ichoku was recognized as 'Kugegogeji Ihaikotonari (公家御下知違背事也)' ("Satamirensho (沙汰未練書)"), and it is thought to have gone against an Emperor's command without a clear reason.

In and after the Middle Ages, the Ichoku was understood as 'punishing all the violations against judgements issued by court nobles' (according to the book called "Satamirensho"), and by people, it is ambiguously thought to have gone against an Emperor's command.

sen.j: 特にこれに該当する公家は勅勘などの公家社会では放逐に相当する処分を受けることもあった。
sen.e: Particularly, there were cases in which court nobles who were applicable to this received a punishment equivalent to an expulsion in a court noble community, such as the emperor's censure.

sen.j: 明治初期の刑法典である『改定律例』278条には「違勅罪」という罪名が置かれて違法とされたが、以後天皇の立憲君主化に伴って違勅そのものが罪に問われることは無くなった。
sen.e: In Article 278 of "Kaiteiritsurei", a criminal code in the beginning Meiji Period, a guilt named 'Ichokuzai' was established as an illegal act, but in line with the subsequent constitutional monarch of Emperors, accusing Ichoku itself of a guilt ceased.

sen.j: ところが、大正政変の際に大正天皇より公家出身の立憲政友会総裁西園寺公望に対して第3次桂内閣への内閣不信任案を撤回させて政友会を内閣に協力させるように勅命が出されたものの、政友会の代議士達は自分達は日本国民の代表であるとして西園寺に突き返させた（1913年2月9日）。
sen.e: In the Taisho Political Crisis, Emperor Taisho issued an imperial command that Kinmochi SAIONJI, president of Rikkenseiyukai (a political party originally organized by Hirobumi ITO) should withdraw a parliamentary motion of non-confidence against the cabinet related to the 3rd Katsura Cabinet and urge Seiyukai to collaborate with the Katsura Cabinet, but the parliamentarians of the Seiyukai made Saionji return the imperial command for the reason that the parliamentarians were the representatives of the Japanese nation (February 9, 1913.)

sen.j: このため、桂内閣は倒れたが、西園寺はこれは違勅罪であると言って総裁の辞表を提出するとそのまま京都に閉居してしまった（2月23日）。
sen.e: As a result, the Katsura Cabinet fell, and Saionji provided a resignation to step down from the president post for the reason that it was Ichokuzai, and went to Kyoto to live (February 23.)
